results.title: Appeals Court Rejects Trump’s Effort to Delay Trial in Fraud Case
results.abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump had sued the judge presiding over his case, Arthur F. Engoron, aiming to pause a trial that will likely begin as soon as Monday.
des_facet: New York State Civil Case Against Trump (452564/2022)

media.caption: Justice Arthur F. Engoron issued an order that found Donald J. Trump liable for fraud by overvaluing his assets, and stripped him of control over his New York properties.

results.title: An Aristocrat’s Grandson, a Precious Desk and a Storage Unit in Queens
results.abstract: Christian Agostino von Hassell lost a trove of family heirlooms intertwined with European history when he encountered New York’s unforgiving laws governing storage lockers.

results.title: After Coming Out as Gay, I’m on the Outs With My Ex-Wife’s Family. Help!
results.abstract: A reader is dreading his son’s engagement party, where he expects to encounter not only his estranged ex-wife, but a constellation of former in-laws.

results.title: North Korea May Have Seen Little Benefit in Keeping U.S. Soldier
results.abstract: Why did the North expel Pvt. Travis T. King, rather than use him for its own purposes? Analysts say he was probably considered more of a burden than an asset.

media.caption: News coverage of North Korea’s deportation of Pvt. Travis King on a TV screen in a Seoul train station on Thursday.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Pop and Rock Music;Kirkman, Terry (1939-2023);Association, The (Music Group)
results.title: Terry Kirkman, Whose Band Was a Late-1960s Hit Machine, Dies at 83
results.abstract: A singer, songwriter and virtuoso musician, he was a founder of the clean-cut group the Association and wrote one of its biggest hits, “Cherish.”

media.caption: Terry Kirkman of the Association in an undated photo. He said that he laid down the basis of the group's enduring hit “Cherish” in a little more than 30 minutes.

results.title: Michael Gambon, Dumbledore in the ‘Harry Potter’ Films, Dies at 82
results.abstract: After he made his mark in London in the 1970s, he went on to play a wide range of roles, including Edward VII, Oscar Wilde and Winston Churchill.

media.caption: Michael Gambon as Professor Albus Dumbledore in “Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince” (2009). He took over the role after Richard Harris, who had originated it, died in 2002.

results.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
results.title: 5 Takeaways From Another Trump-Free Republican Debate
results.abstract: The party’s front-runner took few hits as his rivals bickered, Nikki Haley delivered an assured performance, Tim Scott reasserted himself and Ron DeSantis took his first debate swipes at Trump.

media.caption: The candidates mostly seemed to intentionally ignore former President Donald J. Trump’s overwhelming lead — other than Chris Christie, who took an awkward stab at a nickname (“Donald Duck”).
media.copyright: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times

results.title: New York Is Rebounding for the Rich. Nearly Everyone Else Is Struggling.
results.abstract: The huge income gap between rich and poor in Manhattan is the latest sign that the economic recovery from the pandemic has been lopsided in New York City.

media.caption: New Yorkers at the lower end of the income spectrum have seen their wages stagnate, and some are working excessively to keep up. Khadijah Bethea was working up to 70 hours a week for catering companies.
media.copyright: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times

results.title: House Votes to Strip Defense Secretary of Salary as Right Wing Flexes Muscles
results.abstract: Little more than three days before a government shutdown, the Republican-led House spent the day adding hard-right proposals to a series of doomed spending bills.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

media.caption: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III has become a target of far-right Republicans. Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia declared that he “definitely deserves to be fired.”

results.title: In a Sartorial About-Face, Senate Reverts to Tradition on Its Dress Code
results.abstract: A week after the top Senate Democrat announced a more casual standard for dress in the chamber, a bipartisan pair won passage of a measure requiring that business attire be worn.

media.caption: Senator John Fetterman, Democrat of Pennsylvania, is known for wearing hoodies and shorts instead of suits.

results.abstract: Prosecutors said the former president’s defense team was trying to use an arcane law to derail the scheduled start of his trial on charges of mishandling classified material and obstructing justice.
des_facet: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)

media.caption: Prosecutors in the office of the special counsel, Jack Smith, have been trying to move the case along expeditiously, concerned that former President Donald J. Trump might try to pardon himself if he is re-elected.

results.title: Beloved Tree in England Is Felled in ‘Act of Vandalism’
results.abstract: Locals and tourists mourned the loss of one of Britain’s most photographed trees, which stood for hundreds of years in a dip in Hadrian’s Wall. The police said they had a suspect in custody.

media.caption: The felled tree at Sycamore Gap, beside Hadrian’s Wall, on Thursday. The authorities said they had arrested a 16-year-old boy in connection with what they described as an act of vandalism.
media.copyright: Owen Humphreys/Press Association, via Associated Press

results.title: First Impeachment Hearing Yields No New Information on Biden
results.abstract: In a chaotic session, Republicans accused the president of crime and corruption, but even their witnesses said the case for impeachment hadn’t been made.

media.caption: Representative James R. Comer, the chairman of the Oversight Committee, said his panel would continue to search for more evidence against President Biden.

results.title: Vulnerable Republicans Try to Head Off Blame for Shutdown
results.abstract: Some mainstream House Republicans representing districts won by President Biden have explored a bipartisan stopgap measure as right-wing lawmakers push Congress toward a shutdown.

media.caption: Representative Mike Lawler is one of 18 House Republicans representing a district won by President Biden. They must appeal to constituents ranging from Trump supporters to left-of-center Democrats.

results.byline: By Todd Heisler, Andy Newman, Raúl Vilchis and Olivia Bensimon
results.title: Where the Migrants Who Came to New York Are Living Now
results.abstract: From every corner of the world to every corner of New York City, newcomers are carving out communities in unexpected — and sometimes hostile — places.

media.caption: The new arrivals came to New York from all over the globe. They were scattered to every corner of this city — to over 200 shelters in repurposed hotels, former jails and schools, or enormous tented dormitories with cots so close together that they touch.
